answers.q1: At eBay, I led a cross-functional analysis of our product recommendation engine which was underperforming. I conducted a deep-dive statistical analysis using SQL and Python, identified that our collaborative filtering weights were over-indexed on browse history versus purchase history. I proposed and implemented a reweighting strategy that increased conversion by 12% and generated $90M in incremental revenue. This required synthesizing insights from customer data, A/B test results, and stakeholder input from product, engineering, and business teams.
answers.q2: After five years in data engineering, I realized my impact was limited to optimizing existing systems. I wanted to drive strategic decisions at a higher level. My experience at eBay showed me that the most valuable work happened at the intersection of data, business strategy, and stakeholder alignmentâ€”classic consulting skills. I pursued my Cornell MBA specifically to transition into strategy roles where I could leverage my technical foundation to solve broader business problems.
answers.q3: My quantitative background is my superpower in consulting. I can quickly parse complex datasets, identify patterns others miss, and translate technical findings into executive-friendly narratives. In consulting, this means I can support the analytical rigor while also building trust with C-level clients. My engineering experience taught me to ask the right questions before diving into analysis, which is exactly what consultants do in scoping engagements.
